text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: J.B. Paredis
Present Address: STANTHORPE, Sask.
Pioneer Address: ST. ANTONY, Sask. (discontinued, then railroad name)
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1902
(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the QUESTIONNAIRE.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 3 or 4.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? None.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Quite often, at least once a week.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Mostly Sundays, but also other weekdays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Often by invited homes, but mostly without.

What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Always evenings.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Usually on invitations only. However, people who happened to meet were always welcome.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Usually say "for dinner," there was no potluck, but people provided the food they had on hand.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Most people had something to drink for the visitors.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? When children were old enough, they stayed at home to mind the youngest ones.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Sometimes for building, but this was not very prevalent here.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

In 1902, the first church was erected by a bee lasting 3 or 4 days. 10 to 15 men were working and a few women prepared meals. In 1904, one of the early schools was built by volunteers. This is still in use but completely remodeled.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances, in homes? Describe. Parties such as what or other card games often with dancing were quite common even in the early days and quite inexpensive—often a simple hymn book or a single sheet of paper. These were in farm homes of such small size that we now wonder how we could do it.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. The custom varied in the twenties and is very rare now. For weddings people now hire a hall and a good orchestra.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No schedule of any kind was followed, but there always seemed to be something going on.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

Flower Recreation and Social Life.

REMEMBER VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? 

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? 

4. Were you often invited to other homes or was it visiting done without an invitation? 

What time of the day did you go? 

In the morning and spend the day? 

or in the afternoon? 

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? 

How did the meal usually end? 

Was there always something to drink? 

5. Did the whole family go? Or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? 

6. Did you ever have these when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? 

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, tall- 

ing what the nearest town was then and how often they met. 

7. In the earliest years that you were here were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. 

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. 

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times; every two weeks once a month, etc.? 

Do you always seem to do something afterwards?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

Schools were used in some districts for all kinds of social activities. However, in some districts the school was never used for any except those organized by the school for Christmas programs or other.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

As described above.

9. When was your first community hall built? about 1918.

What material was it made of? Lumber How large was it? 28 x 60

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Individually owned

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc?)

For sometime home parties still continued. However, wedding dances or programs to raise funds were transferred to the hall.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

Yes, in most cases.

How were babies and small children provided for? As a rule, every bed in the house was occupied by someone. In the absence of blankets, they were placed wherever convenient.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

Normally the barns could take care of them. There were stables at schools and churches were taken by neighbors.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

What? 51.

Was there card playing for a prize? Very little.

What dances were popular? Square dances were the most popular. The polka, two step, schottisch, and several others were known by everyone.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

In the early days there were no public parties. They were only in private homes and were invited parties. If you objected to dancing you were not invited.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Everybody played cards or at least had no objections. Some do not like to play cards and just watch others or talk among themselves.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, etc., and other activities. (Include also the school Christian Endeavor, Glee clubs, etc.)

9. When was your first community hall built? What material was it made of? Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, organization, etc.? Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? How large was it? How long did it take the place of houses or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? Did you continue to use the local schoolhouse, gathering hall, etc., or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? How did you pay for the hall?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? How were babies and small children provided for? How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? What card games were popular in the early days?

11. Was there card playing for a prize? What dances were popular? Were there any disagreements between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community or not? For some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for some who frowned upon it, explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "snobbery," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlors, etc.? 

Everything was quite informal.

13. Was the chinaware known in your community? very little.

Describe what you remember about chinaware, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

I have a picture of the first meeting held at our school and the draft shown on the blackboard.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? (Only about 75%)

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? yes

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
2. That attempts at formality or "snobbery" do you remember in small towns and in places not large than calling, calling each other, visiting between socially.

3. Has the absence been in your community among debts.

4. Describe what you remember about differences, calling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

5. Describe any other details of situations, parties, etc., that you remember, calling of any places or occasions not already mentioned that were peculiar at parties and the appearance thereon throughout you can show some changes in visiting or social life become noticeable.

6. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can recollect becoming established in your community?

7. Give the date and reason for its being organized.

8. Was there a Scandinavian Grain Growers' Union in your community?

9. When it was organized, was that group due to its organization.

10. How many members did the first meet have? How many attended regularly the meetings of the farmers in the community belonging to it?

11. How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

12. What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

13. Did there & Scandinavian Club in your district?

14. How was it organized?

15. Approximately how many women belonged to it?

16. Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? All boys were keen on baseball. Their best sport however was trapping gophers.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the names of each, but when it was first organized, its activity, its aims and purposes, who belonged (and when), how many people?, whether it included all people or only an relatively small group (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and also connected with the church, so they need not be included here.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special tutors, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? All of these were very popular. How long ago?

What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   *Foxhounds, sledding.*

   What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   *Mostly crokinole, parcheesi, checkers.*

   Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   *Whole family.*

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   *On the farm, even young boys helped at chores. Older boys did nothing. For example, 10-year-old boys helped stack wood, so they did anything on the farm except milking because all grain was handled in 2 bushels.*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, peppers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   *Possibly those who had time.*

**PICNICS AND SPORTS.**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   *1907, June 12.*

26. Who organized it?  
   *The parish for the church.*

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   *Entire community and even people from other districts came.*

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   *Yes.*

   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   *Baseball, horse races, other races, horseshoes, climbing, greasy pole, etc.*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   *Meals served on grounds you could eat all you wanted for 25¢.*

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   *Food donated by the people mostly produce of the farm with tea & coffee.*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   *Started with Mass at 10 o'clock and lasted all day.*
5. What winter games were played outdoors - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

22. What winter games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Face," "Whist," "Parcheesi," checkers or other board games? 

Weekly entertainments included:

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrows, beads, etc., or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

26. Who organized it? 

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? 

30. That arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? 

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 

Started with breakfast at 10 o'clock and lasted all day.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

I think that what impressed me the most was the parking ground near the station where hundreds of vehicles were left without any further attention and the great variety of them. There were some newly painted wagons but the most of them were wagons pulled by one young fellow had come with a hayrake.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

With the advent of the motor car people travel more and will follow their ball teams to all surrounding towns. There are more people now and for the above reasons many changes.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Since I can remember baseball was most common. Around 1910 there was some interest in hockey but we did not have a hockey team until much later.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

baseball

What year? 1907

How long did it continue? Always had a baseball team except during war.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

None except that around 1912 young people would choose sides to play hockey. No hockey team, however, until much later.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

1910 for hockey, lasted only about 2 yrs.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Our rink was built in 1946. We have both hockey & curling.
35. Describe any differences in habits or customs which you know of at the time when you were younger.

36. Tell about any differences in numbers attending school, family size, etc.

37. What changes have you noticed in pictures since the first years? If possible, describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in them.

38. How long did it continue?

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for.

40. Our rink was built in 1946. We have been using it ever since.
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1907

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community games?

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? The Parent

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 4th). The first games when it was held by

Was there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates. No

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

I was 10 years old and had had very little school. We had no books we could not afford them.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? None

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Few of the old timers could even read. None could afford books.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

Yes, we did later mostly from saloon.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? Usually information such as animals of the world.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates. No

48. Was there a school library? No When was it begun?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Some did.
40. How did an annual report become established in your community? (Give a list of the people who were responsible for starting the first annual report.)

41. Did it grow out of a need for the early library? If so, what was the purpose?

42. What kind of books did you bring with you when you came here? (Give a list of the books you brought, and what kind.)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? (Give details.)

45. How many books did you buy after you came here? (Give details.)

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? (Give details.)

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? (Give details and dates.)

48. Was there a school library? (Give details.)

49. Did parents ever use their children's school textbooks as additional reading material? (Give details.)
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? No
When was it started? — Who started it?
Is it still in existence?
If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

The Parish of St. Antoine has had a fairly good library of French books mostly religious since about 1912. This was usually for loaning out to those who wanted to read. It is still used but apparently not to a great extent.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
We had La Crosse a French language paper and the Family Herald.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.
I get the Daily paper, The Leader Post, and several other magazines back French, English, and incidently I still have the Family Herald.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Yes
Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
Family Herald.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
No we did not think about it.
We had no time.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? 

When was it started? 

Was it still in existence? 

If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it had, who used it, who was in charge, etc.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

53. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

54. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

We did not think about it.

We had no time.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? None.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? None.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the West? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.
   Bought a violin in 1912 (piano in 1922 $350)
   My folks had an organ about 1912.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.
   Singing was an accomplishment everyone had.
   At all parties, everyone present had to sing a song. There was no grand piano but everyone sang.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.
   Most of the singing was without any accompaniment.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?
   Mostly old folk songs — friends.

in the community? Same.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.
   Yes, everyone sang folk songs.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.
   No

63. Was there a band in your community? No When was it started?
   Who started it? — How long did it continue?

   How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?

   What instruments were included?

   Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
Musical Instruments

56. What musical instruments did you have?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to this town?

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs; or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? When was it started? How long did it continue? How many were in it? Who was bandleader? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where it members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

I am a stamp collector but there are few others here.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

No

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

I have played the violin for dancing from 1912 on until about 1940. I have been choir leader in the church for the last 35 years.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

Many of our women were good at such things as knitting, crocheting, work, dressmaking. My own mother was very clever at all these.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give name and dates and photos of public appearances, if any.

65. Is there an important or keen interest in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests:

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, curiosities, etc.? If so, explain.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

General:

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, readings, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary.)
Oxford
